item.title: Problem with my c code
item.dc:creator: @lolsuper lolsuper_
item.description:
@lolsuper wrote:

strcmp(n,i)

im pretty sure the compiler would complain about an implicit conversion of integer to pointer… why? strcmp() takes to char * arguments, but i is a char… the compiler will then convert it to use it as a pointer, but will also give you a head up… what you really need to do is n[0] == i and n[0] == p… actually, i’d just use a char for input and do scanf("%c", &thechar);

Read full topic

item.title: Problem with my c code
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

You have so many errors that it doesn’t even matter whether it compiles or not. In fact, it is probably better if it doesn’t. But anyway, you use strcmp for c-strings, for characters, you use operator ==. Please get a book, I mean no offense but your code is the worst ever. C is a very bad language choice for your apparent learning method (or lack of). I recommend Python, it is easy, it has an intuitive syntax, and you don’t get segfaults.

Read full topic

item.title: Problem with my c code
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

i tried using strcmp and gets, but its not compiling

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdbool.h>
#include <string.h>

int main (void)

{
bool y = false;
char a[] = {0},b[] = {0},c[]={0},d[]={0},e[898];
char n[1];
char i = 'I';
char p = 'P';
do
{
puts("Personal Phone Book Maintenance Program.");
puts("");
puts("Commands are I (insert)");
gets(n);

    if (strcmp(n,i) == 0)
    {

        printf("family name: ");
        gets(a);
        printf("\nfirst name: ");
        gets(b);
        printf("\naddress: ");
        gets(c);
        printf("\nphone number: ");
        gets(d);
        puts("");


    }

    if (strcmp(n,p) == 0)
    {
        puts("My personal phone book");
        printf("family name: %s",a[1]);
        printf("\nfirst name:%s ",b);
        printf("\naddress: %s",c);
        printf("\nphone number:%s ",d);




    }

}

while (!y);
return 0;
}

item.title: Problem with my c code
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

there will still be the newline in the buffer, use gets() instead of getchar() and compare with strcmp() instead of ==

Read full topic

item.title: Problem with my c code
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

the program works fine , but after i enter “I” it automatically skips the reading for family name
can someone tell me whats wrong with it and correct it please.

[code]

// the program works fine , but after i enter “I” it automatically skips the reading for family name

// can someone tell me whats wrong with it and correct it please.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int main (void)

{

char a[100],b[100],c[100],d[100],e[1];

int n;

puts(“Personal Phone Book Maintenance Program.”);

puts("");

puts(“Commands are I (insert)”);

if ( ( ( n = getchar() ) != EOF ))

{

if (n=='I')

{



    printf("family name: ");

    gets(a);

    printf("\nfirst name: ");

    gets(b);

    printf("\naddress: ");

    gets(c);

    printf("\nphone number: ");

    gets(d);

    puts("");





}

}

return 0;

}[/code]
